Prompt:
Example 1:
Cat and Dog walk. They walk in their village. Then they see an egg. The egg is in the grass. The egg is alone in the grass. The egg is all alone. Cat and Dog walk to a bird. They ask the bird, "Is this your egg?" But the bird says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the owl. Maybe it is his egg." Cat and Dog walk to the owl. They ask the owl, "Is this your egg?" But the owl says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the goose. Maybe it is her egg." Cat and Dog walk to the goose. They ask the goose, "Is this your egg?" But the goose says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the two ducks. Maybe it is their egg." Cat and Dog walk to the two ducks. They ask the two ducks, "Is this your egg?" But the two ducks say, "No, that is not our egg." Then the egg breaks.

Example 2:
The Sun’s light shines on Earth. The light makes our air, land, and water warm. But some things get
warmer than others.
Pretend it is a sunny day. If you wore a black shirt, you would feel hot. But if you wore a white shirt, you wouldn’t feel as hot. The dark color absorbs more of the Sun’s energy. That makes the black shirt warm.
Light colors reflect more of the Sun’s energy. This makes the white shirt cooler to wear. See for yourself! You need a piece of black paper and a piece of white paper. You also need two thermometers and a lamp. Ask an adult to help you.
Fold the black paper so it makes a pocket. Do the same thing to the white paper. Next, put a thermometer into the black pocket. Do the same thing to the white pocket. Then put the pockets under the lamp. Turn the lamp on, and wait for 10 minutes. Then check the thermometers.
Which pocket got hotter — the black pocket or the white one? Do you know why?

Humans grow older. When we are little, we can run fast and jump high. As we get older, we can’t run as fast and jump as high. Our bodies change in many ways. Our bones get weaker. Our muscles get smaller. Our skin gets wrinkled. Our eyes don’t see as well. Our hair turns gray. Our teeth get loose. These changes make us feel older. But our brains stay sharp. We learn more and can solve harder problems. That is the way our bodies change as we grow older. It is a natural part of life. We all grow older. It is a beautiful process. As humans grow, their bodies change. They start to feel tired and have trouble walking. Their skin loses its color and starts to wrinkle. Their hair turns gray and falls out. It’s hard to keep the body going when it gets old. But people can still enjoy their lives and do the things they love, even when they get older. They can walk slowly, read books, or play games. They can still have fun.

Human bodies get older. When people are little, they are happy and strong. But as they grow up, they start to feel tired and weak. They can’t run as fast as they used to. Their bodies start to get gray hair and wrinkles. That means their bodies are getting older. When people are old, they need to rest more. They also need help sometimes. But people are always happy to see their family and friends. So, even when our bodies get older, we still have love and happiness.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'human aging' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 100 words. 

As we grow up, our bodies change. Our skin gets wrinkles. Our eyes get less sharp. Our hair turns gray. Our bones get weaker. We move slower. Our hearing gets worse. We need glasses. We need a cane. Our body starts to slow down. It is like a machine that runs out of batteries. But, we still feel happy and love to be with our friends and family. We live in our homes and play with our pets. We are still people and we still have fun. Our bodies just change, but we are still happy. Our lives are still good. 





Answer: 

Our bodies are like machines. They run out of batteries. We get older. Our skin gets wrinkles. Our eyes get less sharp. Our hair turns gray. We move slower. We need help sometimes. But we are still happy. We are still people. We still have fun. We live with our friends and family. We have pets. Our lives are still good

Humans get older. Their bodies change. Our hearts get stronger. Our brains get smarter. But our bodies also get tired. We start to lose our hair and our teeth. Our muscles get weak. We need to rest more. That’s because our bodies are getting older. Some things make our bodies stay healthy longer. Eating fruits and vegetables helps. Exercise makes us strong. We also need to get enough sleep. That’s how our bodies stay healthy. And that’s how we stay young. Even when we are old, we can still be happy. We can still play and have fun. We can still do what we love.
